SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 01–10940. James Edward Price, Petitioner v. United States. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit for further consideration in light of United States v. LaBonte,
520 U. S. 751, 759-760 (1997), and the Solicitor General’s acknowledge-
ment that the Court of Appeals “erred in concluding that petitioner’s
drug possession offense qualified as a predicate felony” under 18
U. S. C. § 924(c) in the absence of notice under 21 U.S.C. § 851(a). Brief
in Opposition 12. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with whom The
Chief Justice and Justice Thomas join. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Kennedy.

                               Opinion
  No. 01–1184. United States, Petitioner v. Francisco Jimenez Recio
and Adrian Lopez-Meza. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Breyer. Opinion by Justice Stevens, concurring in
part and dissenting in part.

  No. 02–306. Beneficial National Bank, et al., Petitioners v. Marie
Anderson, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit granted. Brief of petitioners
to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or
before 3 p.m., Friday, March 7, 2003. Brief of respondents to be filed
with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m.,
Friday, April 4, 2003. Reply brief, if any, to be filed with the Clerk and
served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Wednesday, April
23, 2003. Rule 29.2 does not apply.
  No. 02–371. Virginia, Petitioner v. Kevin Lamont Hicks. Motion of
City of Richmond and Richmond Development & Housing Authority
for leave to file a brief as amici curiae granted. Motion of respondent
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Virginia granted. Brief of petitioner
to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or
before 3 p.m., Friday, March 7, 2003. Brief of respondent to be filed
with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m.,
Friday, April 4, 2003. Reply brief, if any, to filed with the Clerk and
served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Wednesday, April
23, 2003. Rule 29.2 does not apply.

594                      MONDAY, JANUARY 27, 2003

                                 Order
  IT IS ORDERED that the revised Rules of this Court, today ap-
proved by the Court and lodged with the Clerk, shall be effective
May 1, 2003, and be printed as an appendix to the United States
Reports.
  IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the Rules promulgated January
11, 1999, see 525 U. S. 1193, shall be rescinded as of April 30, 2003, and
that the revised Rules shall govern all proceedings in cases commenced
after that date and, to the extent feasible and just, cases then pending.


                         Certiorari Granted
   No. 02–6683. Hernan O’Ryan Castro, Petitioner v. United States.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. In addition to the question pre-
sented by the petition, the parties are directed to brief and argue the
following question: Does this Court have jurisdiction to review the
Eleventh Circuit’s decision affirming the dismissal of a § 2255 petition
for writ of habeas corpus as second or successive?

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, and
Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.
  “Justice Scalia is unable to be present today, but will participate in
the consideration and decision of today’s cases on the basis of the briefs
and transcripts of oral argument. Justice Thomas will take no part in
the consideration or decision of PacifiCare Health Systems, Inc. v. Jef-
frey Book, No. 02–215.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition

   No. 02–6671. James Widner, Petitioner v. James V. Crosby, Jr., Sec-
retary, Florida Department of Corrections. On petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit
for further consideration in light of Carey v. Saffold, 536 U. S. 214
(2002).

   No. 02–7858. Muhammad Abd Saleem Eury, Petitioner v. Gene M.
Johnson, Director, Virginia Department of Corrections, et al. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeat-
edly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept
any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                        Attorney Discipline
  No. D–2336. In the Matter of Discipline of Sergei Nicholas Klimow.
Sergei Nicholas Klimow, of Upland, California, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

practice of law in this Court.

  No. D–2345. In the Matter of Discipline of Jeffrey D. Grant. Jeffrey

law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–2346. In the Matter of Discipline of Charles W. Sullivan.
Charles W. Sullivan, of New York, New York, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

(JOURNAL)               TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 2003                   673
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, and
Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Justice Scalia is unable to be present today, but will participate in
the consideration and decision of today’s cases on the basis of the briefs
and transcripts of oral argument.”

                               Opinions
  No. 01–1420. Washington State Department of Social and Health
Services, et al., Petitioners v. Guardianship Estate of Danny Keffeler,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Washington. Judg-
ment reversed, and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Washing-
ton for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Souter.
  No. 01–7662. Thomas Joe Miller-El, Petitioner v. Janie Cockrell, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy.
Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Thomas.

                          Oral Arguments
   No. 01–1559. Joseph Massaro, Petitioner v. United States. Argued
by Mr. Herald P. Fahringer for the petitioner and by Mr. Srikanth
Srinivasan for the respondent.
   No. 01–1435. Clackamas Gastroenterology Associates, P.C., Peti-

  No. 02–9165. Richard H. Williams, Petitioner v. Texas. Application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia
and by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas denied.

  No. 02–9203. In Re Richard H. Williams, Petitioner. Application for
stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia and
by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of habeas cor-
pus denied.
JNL02$0226—07-31-03 19:43:47       JOURNAPGT           MILES




(JOURNAL)               WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 2003                  675
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, and
Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Justice Scalia is unable to be present today, but will participate in
the consideration and decision of today’s cases on the basis of the briefs
and transcripts of oral argument.”

                                 Opinion

   No. 01–1118. Joseph Scheidler, Andrew Scholberg, Timothy Murphy,
and The Pro-Life Action League, Inc., Petitioners v. National Organiza-
tion for Women, Inc., et al.; and
   No. 01–1119. Operation Rescue, Petitioner v. National Organization
for Women, Inc., et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed, and cases re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by The Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice Ginsburg,
with whom Justice Breyer joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,

                      Order in Pending Case
   No. 02–5664. Charles T. Sell, Petitioner v. United States. Counsel
should be prepared to discuss the jurisdiction of this Court and of the
Court of Appeals in this case, see Cohen v. Beneficial Industrial Loan
Corporation, 337 U. S. 541 (1949), and are directed to file with the
Clerk, and serve upon opposing counsel, supplemental briefs on the
issue on or before 3 p.m., Friday, March 7, 2003. Twenty copies of the
briefs prepared under this Court’s Rule 33.2 may be filed initially in
order to meet the March 7 filing date. Rule 29.2 does not apply. Forty
copies of the briefs prepared under Rule 33.1 are to be filed as soon as
possible thereafter.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 01–8639. Dwayne Coulter, Petitioner v. Illinois. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District. Mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded
to the Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, for further consider-
ation in light of Miller-El v. Cockrell, 537 U. S. ––– (2003).
   No. 02–782. Jonathan R. Walls, Warden, Petitioner v. Demetrius
Henderson. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Motion of respondent for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Woodford v. Visciotti, 537 U. S. ––– (2002).

Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg.

Justice O’Connor join.

curring opinion by Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice Breyer joins.

                        Attorney Discipline

  No. D–2346. In the Matter of Charles W. Sullivan. Charles W. Sulli-
van, of New York, New York, having requested to resign as a member
of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from
the roll of attorneys admitted to the practice of law before this Court.
The Rule to Show Cause, issued on February 24, 2003, is discharged.
  No. D–2347. In the Matter of Discipline of David Caldwell. David
Caldwell, of Dallas, Texas, is suspended from the practice of law in this
Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring him
to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law
in this Court.
  No. D–2348. In the Matter of Discipline of Miles Hartman Apple-
berry. Miles Hartman Appleberry, of San Antonio, Texas, is suspended
from the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable
within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–2349. In the Matter of Discipline of Edward Nicholas Daneri.
Edward Nicholas Daneri, of San Antonio, Texas, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–2350. In the Matter of Discipline of Steven M. Carsey. Steven
M. Carsey, of Fort Worth, Texas, is suspended from the practice of law
in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring
JNL02$0310—07-24-03 18:32:59      JOURNAPGT         MILES




730                       MONDAY, MARCH 10, 2003

him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice
of law in this Court.
   No. D–2351. In the Matter of Discipline of Ronald Bruce Layer. Ron-
ald Bruce Layer, of San Antonio, Texas, is suspended from the practice
of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court. No. D–2352. In the Matter of Discipline
of Dennis Francis Monahan. Dennis Francis Monahan, of Medway, Mas-
sachusetts, is suspended from the practice of law in this Court, and a
rule will issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–2353. In the Matter of Discipline of James Anthony Gibbons.
James Anthony Gibbons, of Clinton, Massachusetts, is suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

                       Order in Pending Case
   No. 02–8286. Delma Banks, Petitioner v. Janie Cockrell, Director,
Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division. Applica-
tion for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
Scalia and by him referred to the Court granted pending the disposi-
tion of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for writ
of certiorari be denied, this stay shall terminate automatically. In the
event the petition for writ of certiorari is granted, the stay shall termi-
nate upon the sending down of the judgment of this Court.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 01–1711. United States ex rel. Anthony J. Dunleavy, Petitioner
v. County of Delaware, Pennsylvania, et al. On petition for writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
for further consideration in light of Cook County v. Chandler, 538 U. S.
––– (2003).
   No. 02–924. Mulvaney Mechanical, Inc., Petitioner v. Sheet Metal
Workers International Association, Local 38. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
for further consideration in light of Howsam v. Dean Witter Reynolds,
Inc., 537 U. S. ––– (2002).

Court for the Central District of California. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to t he United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit de-
nied. Justice O’Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of
this petition.
   No. 02–8432. Gary M. Northington, Petitioner v. Michigan Depart-
ment of Corrections. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of
Appeals of Michigan dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As the petitioner has
repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to
accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner
unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition
submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Co-
lumbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Ste-
vens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
   No. 02–8562. Robert L. Jarrett, Jr., Petitioner v. Mancan, Inc., dba
Manpower, Inc. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8.
   No. 02–8598. Karu Gene White, Petitioner v. Kentucky. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kentucky denied. Justice
Breyer would grant certiorari.

  No. 01–10873. Khanh Phuong Nguyen, Petitioner v. United States,

  No. 01–1862. Jeanne Woodford, Warden, Petitioner v. Robert Fred-
erick Garceau. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Thomas. Opinion by Justice O’Connor concurring in the judg-
ment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter, with whom Justice Gins-
burg and Justice Breyer join.
  No. 01–1269. City of Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio, et al., Petitioners v.
Buckeye Community Hope Foundation, et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment
reversed in part, vacated in part, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O’Connor.
Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice Thomas joins.

JNL02$0327—04-15-03 09:37:37     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                THURSDAY, MARCH 27, 2003                    785
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
                                 Orders
   Ordered:
   1. That Forms 1, 2, 3, and 5 in the Appendix to the Federal Rules of
Appellate Procedure be, and they hereby are, amended by replacing
all references to “19 ” with references to “20 .”
   2. That the foregoing amendments to the forms in the Appendix to
the Federal Rules of Appellate Procedure shall take effect on Decem-
ber 1, 2003, and shall govern in all proceedings in appellate cases there-
after commenced and, insofar as just and practicable, all proceedings
then pending.
   3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Appellate Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072
of Title 28, United States Code.
   Ordered:
   1. That the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein amendments to Bankruptcy
Rules 1005, 1007, 2002, 2003, 2009, and 2016, and new Rule 7007.1.
   2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Bank-
ruptcy Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 2003, and shall gov-
ern in all proceedings in bankruptcy cases thereafter commenced and,
insofar as just and practicable, all proceedings then pending.
   3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Bankruptcy Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section
2075 of Title 28, United States Code.
   Ordered:
   1. That the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure be, and they hereby
are, amended by including therein amendments to Civil Rules 23, 51,
53, 54, and 71A.
   2. That Forms 19, 31, and 32 in the Appendix to the Federal Rules
of Civil Procedure be, and they hereby are, amended by replacing all
references to “19 ” with references to “20 .”
JNL02$0327—04-15-03 09:37:37    JOURNAPGT          MILES




786                     THURSDAY, MARCH 27, 2003

  3. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Civil Pro-
cedure shall take effect on December 1, 2003, and shall govern in all
proceedings in civil cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as just
and practicable, all proceedings then pending.
  4. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Civil Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of
Title 28, United States Code.
  Ordered:
  1. That the Federal Rules of Evidence be, and they hereby are,
amended by including therein the amendments to Evidence Rule
608(b).
  2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Evidence
shall take effect on December 1, 2003, and shall govern in all proceed-
ings thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and practicable, all pro-
ceedings then pending.
  3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Evidence in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of Title 28,
United States Code.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                 Certiorari–Summary Disposition

  No. 02–1. Thomas R. Phillips, Chief Justice, Supreme Court of Texas,
et al., Petitioners v. Washington Legal Foundation, et al. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Brown v. Legal Foundation
of Washington, 538 U. S. ––– (2003).

                     Orders in Pending Cases

   No. 02M77. Joanne Clark, Petitioner v. William L. Henninger, Dep-
uty Sheriff. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of
certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. 02–473. United States, Petitioner v. Lashawn Lowell Banks. Mo-
tion for appointment of counsel granted, and it is ordered that Randall
J. Roske, Esquire, of Las Vegas, Nevada, is appointed to serve as coun-
sel for the respondent in this case.
   No. 02–8863. Willie C. Jacox, Petitioner v. Gordon England, Secre-
tary of the Navy, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed
in forma pauperis denied. Petitioner allowed until April 21, 2003,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to
submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this
Court.

missed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s
process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any further petitions in
JNL02$0331—04-15-03 07:39:11     JOURNAPGT          MILES




                          MONDAY, MARCH 31, 2003                    803
noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee required
by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in compliance with Rule
33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1
(1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases
cited therein.
   No. 02–9024. Daphne Rodenbaugh, Petitioner v. Mark A.
Ciavarella, Jr. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris denied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As
petitioner has repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is di-
rected not to accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from
petitioner unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and
petition submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District
of Columbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice
Stevens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                      Habeas Corpus Denied

  No. 02–9445. In Re Parnell Seaton, Petitioner. Motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of
habeas corpus dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly
abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any
further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
  No. 02–9579. In Re Jonathan Steele, Petitioner. Motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of
habeas corpus dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly
abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any
further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                               Opinions
  No. 01–1289. State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company,
Petitioner v. Inez Preece Campbell and Matthew C. Barneck, Special
Administrator and Personal Representative of the Estate of Curtis B.
JNL02$0407—04-16-03 16:56:56    JOURNAPGT          MILES




836                       MONDAY, APRIL 7, 2003

Campbell. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Utah. Judg-
ment reversed, and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Utah for
further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Ginsburg.
  No. 02–215. PacifiCare Health Systems, Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
Jeffrey Book, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Scalia. Justice Thomas took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
  No. 01–1107. Virginia, Petitioner v. Barry Elton Black, Richard J.
Elliott, and Jonathan O’Mara. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Virginia. Judgment affirmed in part, and vacated in part, and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Virginia for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Justice O’Connor
announced the judgment of the Court, and delivered the opinion of the
Court with respect to Parts I, II, and III, and an opinion with respect
to Parts IV and V, in which The Chief Justice, Justice Stevens, and
Justice Breyer join. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by
Justice Scalia, with whom Justice Thomas joins as to Parts I and II,
concurring in part, concurring in the judgment in part, and dissenting
in part. Opinion by Justice Souter, with whom Justice Kennedy and
Justice Ginsburg join, concurring in the judgment in part and dissent-
ing in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas.

                   Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 01–1722. San Paolo U. S. Holding Company, Inc., Petitioner v.
Lionel Simon, dba Liberty Paper Company. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate Dis-
trict. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and
case remanded to the Court of Appeal of California, Second Appellate
District, for further consideration in light of State Farm v. Campbell,
538 U. S. ––– (2003).
   No. 02–130. DeKalb Genetics Corporation, Petitioner v. Bayer Crop-
Science, S. A. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for further consideration in
light of State Farm v. Campbell, 538 U. S. ––– (2003).
   No. 02–342. Key Pharmaceuticals, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Freder-
ick D. Edwards. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Ap-
peals of Oregon. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va-
cated, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Oregon for further
consideration in light of State Farm v. Campbell, 538 U. S. ––– (2003).
Justice Breyer took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
   No. 02–370. Anchor Hocking, Inc., Petitioner v. Arleen E. Waddill.

remanded to the Court of Appeals of Oregon for further consideration
in light of State Farm v. Campbell, 538 U. S. ––– (2003).

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                               Opinions

   No. 01–593. Dole Food Company, et al., Petitioners v. Gerardo Den-
nis Patrickson, et al.; and
   No. 01–594. Dead Sea Bromine Co., Ltd., and Bromine Compounds
Limited, Petitioners v. Gerardo Dennis Patrickson, et al. On writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Writ of certiorari in No. 01–593 dismissed, and judgment in No. 01–594
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Opinion by Justice Breyer, with
whom Justice O’Connor joins, concurring in part and dissenting in part.
   No. 02–258. Susan Jinks, Petitioner v. Richland County, South Caro-
lina, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Caro-
lina. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the Supreme Court of
South Carolina for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Concurring opinion by
Justice Souter.
   No. 01–1435. Clackamas Gastroenterology Associates, P. C., Peti-
tioner v. Deborah Wells. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ginsburg,
with whom Justice Breyer joins.

                           Oral Arguments

  No. 02–722. American Insurance Association, et al., Petitioners v.
John Garamendi, Insurance Commissioner, State of California. Argued
by Mr. Kenneth S. Geller for the petitioners, by Mr. Edwin S. Kneedler
for the United States as amicus curiae, by special leave of the Court,
supporting the petitioners, and by Mr. Frank Kaplan for the
respondent.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

Maryland. Motion of the Audubon Naturalist Society for leave to file a

cial Master set for oral argument in due course.

   No. 02–9193. Kamal B. Mahdavi, Petitioner v. The 100 Federal,
State, County, and City Officials, etc., et al. Motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied, and petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly abused this
Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any further peti-
tions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the docketing fee
required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in compliance
with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals,
506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4,
and cases cited therein.
   No. 02–9338. K. Kay Shearin, Petitioner v. Town of Elsmere, Dela-
ware. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis de-
nied, and petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Dela-
ware dismissed. See Rule 39.8.

   No. 02–69. Joseph C. Roell, Petra Garibay, and James Reagan, Peti-
tioners v. Jon Michael Withrow. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Souter. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Thomas, with whom Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, and Justice Ken-
nedy join.
   No. 01–1491. Charles Demore, District Director, San Francisco Dis-
trict of Immigration and Naturalization Service, et al., Petitioners v.
Hyung Joon Kim. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
The Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy. Opinion by
Justice O’Connor, with whom Justice Scalia and Justice Thomas join,
concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Opinion announced
by Justice Souter, with whom Justice Stevens and Justice Ginsburg
join, concurring in part and dissenting in part. Opinion by Justice
Breyer, concurring in part and dissenting in part.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice O’Connor, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                        Opinion Per Curiam

   No. 02–5636. Robert Kaupp, Petitioner v. Texas. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Texas, Fourteenth District.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals of Texas, Fourteenth District for fur-
ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion per curiam.

                Certiorari—Summary Disposition

  No. 01–1459. William Riley, Jr., Interim District Director, Bureau of
Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Petitioner v. Sabrija Radoncic.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit. Motion of Washington Legal Foundation, et al.,
for leave to file a brief as amici curiae granted. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Demore v. Kim, 538 U. S. ––– (2003).
  No. 01–1616. Scott Weber, Interim District Director, Bureau of Im-
migration and Customs Enforcement, Petitioner v. Phu Chan Hoang,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further consideration in light of De-
more v. Kim, 538 U. S. ––– (2003).
  No. 01–1752. Scott Weber, Interim District Director, Bureau of Im-

Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further consideration in light of

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

  No. 02–10539. Carl J. Isaacs, Petitioner v. Frederick Head, Warden.
Application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia denied. Justice
Thomas took no part in the consideration or decision of this application
and this petition.

   No. 02–10519. In Re Carl J. Isaacs, Petitioner. Application for stay
of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy and by
him referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of habeas corpus
denied. Justice Stevens and Justice Breyer would grant the application
for stay of execution. Justice Thomas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this application and this petition.

                      Order in Pending Cases
  No. 02M98. Mitch McConnell, et al., Appellants v. Federal Election
Commission, et al.; and
  No. 02M99. Federal Election Commission, et al., Appellants v. Mitch
McConnell, et al. Motions to dispense with printing the District Court’s
opinions denied. All appellants are directed to file forty copies of a
single appendix prepared in compliance with Rule 33.1 containing the
District Court’s opinions, which will serve as an appendix to all juris-
dictional statements.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and
Justice Ginsburg.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                         Opinion Per Curiam
  No. 02–1212. City of Los Angeles, California, Petitioner v. Edwin F.
David. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 02–1096. Ford Motor Company, Petitioner v. Estate of Tommy
Smith, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Kentucky. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Kentucky for further con-
sideration in light of State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Com-
pany v. Campbell, 538 U. S. ––– (2003).
  No. 02–1097. Ford Motor Company, Petitioner v. Juan Ramon Romo,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of Cali-
fornia, Fifth Appellate District. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Court of Appeal of Cali-
fornia, Fifth Appellate District, for further consideration in light of
State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company v. Campbell, 538
U. S. ––– (2003).

  No. 02–9514. Scott A. Heimermann, Petitioner v. Martin E. Kohler.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied,
and petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Wisconsin,
District I, dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has repeatedly
abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any
further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
  No. 02–9895. Grant Anderson, Petitioner v. Jake Mendez, Warden.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied,
and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Third Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has re-
peatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept
any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court
of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents.
See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.

                               Opinions
  No. 02–281. Inyo County, California, et al., Petitioners v. Paiute-
Shoshone Indians of the Bishop Community of the Bishop Colony, et al.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Gins-
burg. Opinion by Justice Stevens, concurring in the judgment.
  No. 02–337. Phillip T. Breuer, Petitioner v. Jim’s Concrete of Bre-
vard, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Souter.
  No. 01–188. Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of
America, Petitioner v. Peter E. Walsh, Acting Commissioner, Maine
Department of Human Services, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment af-
JNL02$0519—06-05-03 13:59:38     JOURNAPGT        MILES




972                       MONDAY, MAY 19, 2003

firmed. Justice Stevens announced the judgment of the Court, and de-
livered the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I, II, III, and
VI, an opinion with respect to Parts IV and VII, in which Justice
Souter, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join, and an opinion with
respect to Part V, in which Justice Souter and Justice Ginsburg join.
Opinion by Justice Breyer, concurring in part and concurring in the
judgment. Opinion by Justice Scalia, concurring in the judgment. Opin-
ion by Justice Thomas, concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice
O’Connor, with whom The Chief Justice and Justice Kennedy join, con-
curring in part and dissenting in part.
   No. 02–524. Janette Price, Warden, Petitioner v. Duyonn Andre Vin-
cent. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by The Chief
Justice.

  Adjourned until Tuesday, May 27, 2003, at 10 o’clock.


                        Order in Pending Case
   No. 02A952. Republic of Austria, et al., Applicants v. Maria Altmann.
Application for stay of mandate presented to Justice O’Connor and by
her referred to the Court granted pending the disposition of the peti-
tion for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for writ of certiorari be
denied, this stay shall terminate automatically. In the event the peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted, the stay shall terminate upon the
sending down of the judgment of this Court.
JNL02$0527—06-03-03 06:50:55      JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                  TUESDAY, MAY 27, 2003                      979
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                         Opinion Per Curiam
   No. 02–8636. Clyde Timothy Bunkley, Petitioner v. Florida. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of Florida for further proceedings not inconsistent with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by
The Chief Justice, with whom Justice Kennedy and Justice Thomas
join.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 02–983. Frank Cass, Petitioner v. Patricia Love Stephens, et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Texas,
Eighth District. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va-
cated, and case remanded to the Court of Appeals of Texas, Eighth
District, for further consideration in light of State Farm Mutual Auto-
mobile Insurance Company v. Campbell, 538 U. S. ––– (2003).

                      Orders in Pending Cases
   No. 02M95. Stephen W. Carlson, Petitioner v. United States. Motion
to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time
denied.
   No. 02M96. William J. McCorkle, Petitioner v. United States. Motion
for leave to file a petition for writ of certiorari under seal denied with-
out prejudice to filing a renewed motion together with a redacted peti-
tion for writ of certiorari within 30 days.
   No. 126, Original. State of Kansas, Plaintiff v. State of Nebraska
and State of Colorado. Motion of the Special Master for allowance of
fee and disbursements granted, and the Special Master is awarded a
JNL02$0527—06-03-03 06:50:55     JOURNAPGT          MILES




980                        TUESDAY, MAY 27, 2003

total of $145,182.45 for the period July 1, 2002, through April 15, 2003,
to be paid equally by the parties.
  No. 128, Original. State of Alaska, Plaintiff v. United States of
America. Motion of the Special Master for allowance of fees and reim-
bursement granted, and the Special Master is awarded a total of
$57,264.08 for the period October 17, 2002, through April 16, 2003, to
be paid equally by the parties.

                         Certiorari Granted

  No. 02–1290. United States Postal Service, Petitioner v. Flamingo
Industries (USA) Ltd., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
   No. 02–964. George H. Baldwin, Petitioner v. Michael Reese. Motion
of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit granted.
  No. 02–1348. Olympic Airways, Petitioner v. Rubina Husain, Indi-
vidually, and as Personal Representative of the Estate of Abid M. Han-
son, Deceased, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. Justice Breyer took no
part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied,
and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit dismissed. See Rule 39.8. As petitioner has
repeatedly abused this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to
accept any further petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner
unless the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition
submitted in compliance with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Co-
lumbia Court of Appeals, 506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Ste-
vens dissents. See id., at 4, and cases cited therein.
   No. 02–10299. Helen Yee-Fong Chung, Petitioner v. Charles Meyers,
Warden, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Third Circuit before judgment denied.

                               Opinions
   No. 02–469. The Black & Decker Disability Plan, Petitioner v. Ken-
neth L. Nord. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Ginsburg.
   No. 01–1444. Ben Chavez, Petitioner v. Oliverio Martinez. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Justice Thomas announced the judgment
of the Court and delivered an opinion. Justice Souter delivered an opin-
ion, Part II of which is the opinion of the Court, and Part I of which
is an opinion concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Scalia,
concurring in part in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Stevens, concur-
ring in part and dissenting in part. Opinion by Justice Kennedy, with
whom Justice Stevens joins, and with whom Justice Ginsburg joins as
to Parts II and III, concurring in part and dissenting in part. Opinion
by Justice Ginsburg, concurring in part and dissenting in part.
   No. 02–196. National Park Hospitality Association, Petitioner v. De-
partment of the Interior, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas. Opinion
by Justice Stevens, concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Breyer, with whom Justice O’Connor joins.
   No. 01–1368. Nevada Department of Human Resources, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Williams Hibbs, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by The Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice Souter,
with whom Justice Ginsburg and Justice Breyer join. Opinion by Jus-
JNL02$0527—06-03-03 06:50:55     JOURNAPGT          MILES




                           TUESDAY, MAY 27, 2003                  999
tice Stevens, concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy, with whom Justice
Scalia and Justice Thomas join.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, JUNE 2, 2003                    1005
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and
Justice Ginsburg.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                           Opinion Per Curiam

  No. 02–1295. The Citizens Bank, Petitioner v. Alafabco, Inc., et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Alabama for further proceedings
not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.

                   Certiorari—Summary Disposition

   No. 01–1840. Delta Family-Care Disability and Survivorship Plan,
Petitioner v. Frank Regula. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of Bert
Bell/Pete Rozelle NFL Player Retirement Plan for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae granted. Motion of ERISA Industry Committee for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted. Petition for writ of cer-
tiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration
in light of Black & Decker Disability Plan v. Nord, 538 U. S. –––
(2003).

for reconsideration of order denying leave to proceed in forma pau-

JNL02$0602—08-11-03 16:39:02     JOURNAPGT          MILES




1016                       MONDAY, JUNE 2, 2003

this Court’s process, the Clerk is directed not to accept any further
petitions in noncriminal matters from petitioner unless the docketing
fee required by Rule 38(a) is paid and petition submitted in compliance
with Rule 33.1. See Martin v. District of Columbia Court of Appeals,
506 U. S. 1 (1992) (per curiam). Justice Stevens dissents. See id., at 4,
and cases cited therein.

                         Mandamus Denied
   No. 02–9897. In Re David Duane Brewer, Petitioner; and
   No. 02–10054. In Re Donald E. Flynn, Petitioner. Petitions for writs
of mandamus denied.

   No. 02–1202. eWealth USA, Inc., eWealth America, Inc., Argent

   No. 02–7812. James Robert Rice, Petitioner v. Dan L. Dove, War-
den, et al.;
   No. 02–8445. Steve Tataii, Petitioner v. Dwayne D. Yoshina;
   No. 02–8579. John Lee Giegler, Petitioner v. David Jamrog, Warden;
   No. 02–8837. Brian Martinez, Petitioner v. New York;

   No. 02–9121. William James Condit, Petitioner v. Mike Kemna,

ing denied.
   No. 01–10795. Michael Anthony Brown, Petitioner v. James V.
Crosby, Jr., Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. Motion for
leave to file a petition for rehearing denied.

                               Opinions

  No. 02–299. Entergy Louisiana, Inc., Petitioner v. Louisiana Public
Service Commission, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court
of Louisiana. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the Supreme
Court of Louisiana for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas.
  No. 02–428. Dastar Corporation, Petitioner v. Twentieth Century
Fox Film Corporation, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Scalia. Justice Breyer took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this case.
  No. 02–306. Beneficial National Bank, et al., Petitioners v. Marie
Anderson, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia, with
whom Justice Thomas joins.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

lants v. Federal Election Commission, et al.;
   No. 02–1675. National Rifle Association, et al., Appellants v. Federal
Election Commission, et al.;

lants v. Federal Election Commission, et al.;
   No. 02–1734. American Civil Liberties Union, Appellant v. Federal
Election Commission, et al.;
   No. 02–1740. Victoria Jackson Gray Adams, et al., Appellants v. Fed-
eral Election Commission, et al.;
   No. 02–1747. Ron Paul, United States Congressman, et al., Appel-
lants v. Federal Election Commission, et al.;
   No. 02–1753. California Democratic Party, et al., Appellants v. Fed-
eral Election Commission, et al.;
   No. 02–1755. American Federation of Labor and Congress of Indus-
trial Organizations, et al., Appellants v. Federal Election Commission,
et al.; and
   No. 02–1756. Chamber of Commerce of the United States, et al.,
Appellant v. Federal Election Commission, et al. In these cases proba-
ble jurisdiction noted. Cases are consolidated and a total of four hours
is allotted for oral argument. Briefs of the parties who were plaintiffs
in the District Court are to address the questions presented in the
jurisdictional statements and are to be filed with the Clerk of the Court
and served upon the parties who were defendants in the District Court
on or before 3 p.m., Tuesday, July 8, 2003. Briefs of the parties who
were defendants in the District Court are to be filed with the Clerk of
the Court and served upon the parties who were plaintiffs in the Dis-
JNL02$0605—08-11-03 16:42:11    JOURNAPGT         MILES




1026                     THURSDAY, JUNE 5, 2003

trict Court on or before 3 p.m., Tuesday, August 5, 2003. Any reply
briefs by parties who were plaintiffs in the District Court are to be
filed with the Clerk of the Court and served upon parties who were
defendants in the District Court on or before 3 p.m., Thursday, August
21, 2003. Cases are set for oral argument at 10:00 a.m., Monday, Sep-
tember 8, 2003.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, JUNE 9, 2003                     1027
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and
Justice Ginsburg.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 02–312. H & R Block, Inc., Petitioner v. Marie Anderson, et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit. The Court reversed the judgment below in
Beneficial National Bank v. Anderson, 539 U. S. ––– (2003). Therefore,
petition for writ of certiorari granted, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further
proceedings.

                      Orders in Pending Cases
  No. 02A932. Subalecthumy Vengadasalam, Applicant v. John D. Ash-
croft, Attorney General, et al. Application for stay addressed to Justice
O’Connor and referred to the Court denied.
  No. 02M100. Karen H. Pfeiffer, etc., Petitioner v. Georgia Depart-
ment of Transportation. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for
writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.

                         Certiorari Granted
  No. 02–1343. Engine Manufacturers Association and Western States
Petroleum Association, Petitioners v. South Coast Air Quality Manage-
ment District, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
  No. 02–9410. Michael D. Crawford, Petitioner v. Washington. Motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Washington granted.

                         Certiorari Denied
   No. 02–529. Transmission Agency of Northern California, Petitioner
v. Sierra Pacific Power Company, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.

                                Opinions
   No. 02–679. Desert Palace, Inc., dba Caesars Palace Hotel & Casino,
Petitioner v. Catharina F. Costa. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Thomas. Concurring opinion by Justice O’Connor.
   No. 01–950. Hillside Dairy Inc., A&A Dairy, L&S Dairy, and Milky
Way Farms, Petitioners v. William J. Lyons, Jr., Secretary, California
Department of Food and Agriculture, et al.; and
   No. 01–1018. Ponderosa Dairy, Pahrump Dairy, Rockview Dairies,
Inc., and D. Kuiper Dairy, Petitioners v. William J. Lyons, Jr., Secretary,
California Department of Food and Agriculture, et al. On writs of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment vacated, and cases remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by
Justice Thomas, concurring in part and dissenting in part.
   No. 01–10873. Khanh Phuong Nguyen, Petitioner v. United States,
et al.; and
   No. 02–5034. Tuyet Mai Thi Phan, Petitioner v. United States. On
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgments vacated, and cases remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice, with whom Justice Scalia,
Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join.
   No. 02–695. Michael Fitzgerald, Treasurer of Iowa, Petitioner v.
Racing Association of Central Iowa, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
JNL02$0609—06-16-03 19:02:06     JOURNAPGT         MILES




1042                       MONDAY, JUNE 9, 2003

Supreme Court of Iowa. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
Supreme Court of Iowa for further proceedings not inconsistent with
the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Breyer, announced by The
Chief Justice.
  No. 02–271. Dow Chemical Company, et al., Petitioners v. Daniel
Raymond Stephenson, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. With respect to respondents
Joe Isaacson and Phyllis Lisa Isaacson, judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
for further consideration in light of Syngenta Crop Protection, Inc. v.
Henson, 537 U. S. 28 (2002). With respect to respondents Daniel Ray-
mond Stephenson, Susan Stephenson, Daniel Anthony Stephenson, and
Emily Elizabeth Stephenson, judgment affirmed by an equally divided
Court. Opinion per curiam, announced by The Chief Justice. Justice
Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, JUNE 16, 2003                      1055
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “Today’s orders of the Court have been duly entered and certified,
and filed with the Clerk, and they will not be otherwise announced.”
                    Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 01–1865. Meredith Oden, Petitioner v. Northern Marianas Col-
lege. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Ngu-
yen v. United States, 539 U. S. ––– (2003).
                      Orders in Pending Cases
  No. 02M101. Kenneth McKenzie, Petitioner v. Joseph Brooks, War-
den. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari
out-of-time denied.
  No. 02M102. John Parks Trowbridge, Petitioner v. Department of
Treasury, et al. Motion for leave to file an objection in the nature of a
writ of error denied.
  No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
Motion of the River Master for fees and reimbursement of expenses
granted, and the River Master is awarded a total of $7,172.37 for the
period January 1, 2003, through March 31, 2003.
  No. 132, Original. State of Alabama, et al., Plaintiffs v. State of
North Carolina. Motion for leave to file a bill of complaint granted.
Defendant allowed thirty days within which to file an answer.
  No. 02–1318. Zapata Hermanos Sucesores, S. A., Petitioner v.
Hearthside Baking Company, Inc., dba Maurice Lenell Cooky Com-
pany. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case express-
ing the views of the United States.
                         Certiorari Granted
   No. 02–1016. Lee M. Till, et ux., Petitioners v. SCS Credit Corpora-
tion. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit granted.
JNL02$0616—07-11-03 09:58:40      JOURNAPGT         MILES




1056                       MONDAY, JUNE 16, 2003

   No. 02–9065. Shakur Muhammad, aka John E. Mease, Petitioner v.
Mark Close. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris granted, and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted limited to the following
Questions: 1. Whether a plaintiff who wishes to bring a § 1983 suit
challenging only the conditions, rather than the fact or duration, of his
confinement, must satisfy the favorable termination requirement of
Heck v. Humphrey. 2. Whether a prison inmate who has been, but is
no longer, in administrative segregation may bring a § 1983 suit chal-
lenging the conditions of his confinement (i. e. his prior placement in
administrative segregation) without first satisfying the favorable ter-
mination requirement of Heck v. Humphrey. Corinne Beckwith, Esq.,
of Washington, D. C., is appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner
in this case.
                          Certiorari Denied

                               Opinions

  No. 02–5664. Charles Thomas Sell, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Breyer.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice O’Connor and
Justice Thomas join.
JNL02$0616—07-11-03 09:58:40       JOURNAPGT           MILES




                            MONDAY, JUNE 16, 2003                      1073
   No. 02–403. Federal Election Commission, Petitioner v. Christine
Beaumont, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice
Souter. Opinion by Justice Kennedy concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Thomas, with whom Justice Scalia joins.
   No. 02–94. William Overton, Director, Michigan Department of Cor-
rections, et al., Petitioners v. Michelle Bazzetta, et al. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Concurring opinion by
Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Souter, Justice Ginsburg, and Jus-
tice Breyer join. Opinion by Justice Thomas, with whom Justice Scalia
joins, concurring in the judgment.
   No. 02–371. Virginia, Petitioner v. Kevin Lamont Hicks. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Virginia. Judgment reversed, and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Virginia for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Scalia. Concurring opinion by Justice Souter, with whom Justice
Breyer joins.

   No. 02–1756. Chamber of Commerce of the United States, et al.,
Appellants v. Federal Election Commission, et al. The briefs of the
parties who were plaintiffs in the District Court are not to exceed
50 pages for the opening briefs and 20 pages for the reply briefs, except
that the plaintiffs in No. 02–1674 may file an opening brief not to exceed
75 pages, and the political party plaintiffs in Nos. 02–1727, 02–1733,
and 02–1753 may file a consolidated opening brief not to exceed 100
pages. The Solicitor General may file a brief not to exceed 140 pages,
and the intervenor-defendants may file a brief not to exceed 75 pages.

(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, JUNE 23, 2003                    1081
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer. Today’s orders of the Court have been
duly entered and certified, and filed with the Clerk.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 02–7118. Aaron Gomes, aka Lamont Keaton, Petitioner v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in light of Sell
v. United States, 539 U. S. ––– (2003).

                     Orders in Pending Cases
   No. 02M76. In Re Patricia J. Herring, et al., Petitioners. Motion for
leave to file a petition for writ of error coram nobis denied.
   No. 02M103. Michael Wayne Hall, Petitioner v. Texas. Motion for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency
executed by petitioner granted.
   No. 01–1531. Raymond J. Maynes, Jr., Petitioner v. Colorado. Motion
of petitioner to strike the petition for writ of certiorari denied.

                        Certiorari Granted
  No. 02–1389. United States, Petitioner v. Abel Cosmo Galletti, et al.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit granted.

souri, Petitioner v. Missouri Municipal League, et al.;

a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.

                            Recess Order
  The Court will take a recess from Monday, June 23, 2003, until Thurs-
day, June 26, 2003.

                                Opinions
   No. 02–634. Green Tree Financial Corp., nka Conseco Finance Corp.,
Petitioner v. Lynn W. Bazzle, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of South Carolina. Judgment vacated, and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court of South Carolina for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Justice Breyer
announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion in which
Justice Scalia, Justice Souter, and Justice Ginsburg join. Opinion by
Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment and dissenting in part. Dis-
senting opinion by The Chief Justice, with whom Justice O’Connor and
Justice Kennedy join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas.
   No. 02–722. American Insurance Association, et al., Petitioners v.
John Garamendi, Insurance Commissioner, State of California. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice Souter. Dissenting opinion
announced by Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice Stevens, Justice
Scalia, and Justice Thomas join.
   No. 02–241. Barbara Grutter, Petitioner v. Lee Bollinger, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice O’Connor. Concurring
opinion by Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice Breyer joins. Opinion
by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice Thomas joins, concurring in part
and dissenting in part. Opinion by Justice Thomas, with whom Justice
Scalia joins as to Parts I-VII, concurring in part and dissenting in part.
Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice, with whom Justice Scalia,
Justice Kennedy, and Justice Thomas join. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Kennedy.
   No. 02–361. United States, et al., Appellants v. American Library
Association, Inc., et al. On appeal from the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Judgment reversed.
The Chief Justice announced the judgment of the Court and delivered
an opinion in which Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia, and Justice
JNL02$0623—07-15-03 06:45:48     JOURNAPGT        MILES




                          MONDAY, JUNE 23, 2003                 1101
Thomas joined. Opinion by Justice Kennedy concurring in the judg-
ment. Opinion by Justice Breyer concurring in the judgment. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter,
with whom Justice Ginsburg joins.
   No. 02–516. Jennifer Gratz and Patrick Hamacher, Petitioners v. Lee
Bollinger, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed with respect to that
portion of the United States District Court for the Eastern District
of Michigan’s decision granting respondents summary judgment with
respect to liability, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by The Chief Justice. Concur-
ring opinion by Justice O’Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice
Thomas. Opinion by Justice Breyer concurring in the judgment. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Souter joins.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter, with whom Justice Ginsburg
joins as to Part II. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ginsburg, with whom
Justice Souter joins.


  Adjourned until Thursday, June 26, 2003, at 10 o’clock.
JNL02$0626—07-14-03 19:17:31     JOURNAPGT         MILES




(JOURNAL)                THURSDAY, JUNE 26, 2003                  1103
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                               Opinions

  No. 01–1757. Marion Reynolds Stogner, Petitioner v. California. On
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, First Appellate
District. Judgment reversed. Opinion by Justice Breyer. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Kennedy, with whom The Chief Justice, Justice
Scalia, and Justice Thomas join.
   No. 02–102. John Geddes Lawrence and Tyron Garner, Petitioners
v. Texas. On writ of certiorari to Court of Appeals of Texas, Fourteenth
District. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Opinion by Justice O’Connor con-
curring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion announced by Justice
Scalia, with whom The Chief Justice and Justice Thomas join. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Thomas.
  No. 02–182. Georgia, Appellant v. John Ashcroft, Attorney General,
et al. On appeal from the United States District Court for the District
of Columbia. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of Columbia for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
O’Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy. Concurring opinion
by Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter, with whom
Justice Stevens, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join.
   No. 02–311. Kevin Wiggins, Petitioner v. Sewall Smith, Warden,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice O’Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice
Thomas joins.
  No. 02–575. Nike, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Marc Kasky. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of California. Writ of certiorari dis-
missed as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam announced by
The Chief Justice. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom
Justice Ginsburg joins, and with whom Justice Souter joins as to Part
JNL02$0626—07-14-03 19:17:31     JOURNAPGT         MILES




1104                     THURSDAY, JUNE 26, 2003

III. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Breyer, with whom Justice O’Connor joins.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “I am authorized to announce that the Court has acted on all cases
submitted for decision this Term, with the exception of the Bipartisan
Campaign Reform Act cases. Disposition of items scheduled for Confer-
ence will be reflected on the Order List that will be released at 10:00
a.m. tomorrow. Accordingly, it is ordered that those cases remaining on
the docket, but not ready for consideration are continued to the session
of the Court beginning October 6, 2003.
   “The Court will be in recess from today until Monday, September 8,
2003, at which time the Court will hear oral argument in the Bipartisan
Campaign Reform Act cases.
   “The Court today notes the retirement of Librarian Shelley Dowling.
Ms. Dowling served capably as the Court’s Librarian for almost fifteen
years. The Court thanks her for her dedicated service. We wish her
well in her retirement. The Court has appointed Judith A. Gaskell as
the Librarian.
   “The Court members thank all Supreme Court employees for their
outstanding work and their dedication to duty during this Term. The
Court, the Bar, and the public recognize the hard work, commitment,
and professionalism of the Court staff. The work by the Court staff
contributes significantly to the accomplishment of the Court’s mission.”


  Adjourned until Monday, September 8, 2003, at 10 o’clock.
JNL02$0627—08-11-03 16:45:06     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                  FRIDAY, JUNE 27, 2003                    1105
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                   Appeal—Summary Disposition

  No. 02–1577. City of Combes, Texas, et al., Appellants v. East Rio
Hondo Water Supply Corporation, et al. Appeal from the United States
District Court for the Southern District of Texas. Judgment affirmed.

                   Certiorari—Summary Disposition

   No. 02–583. Matthew R. Limon, Petitioner v. Kansas. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Kansas. Petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals of Kansas for further consideration in light of Law-
rence v. Texas, 539 U. S. ––– (2003).
   No. 02–733. Gerling Global Reinsurance Corp. of America, et al.,
Petitioners v. John Garamendi, Insurance Commissioner, State of Cali-
fornia. The Court reversed the judgment below in American Insur-
ance Association v. Garamendi, 539 U. S. ––– (2003). Therefore, peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings.

                        Orders in Pending Cases

   No. 02M89. Sandy Medina, Petitioner v. United States. Renewed
motion for leave to file a petition for writ of certiorari under seal with
redacted copies for the public record granted.
   No. 02M104. Robert Michael Standard, Petitioner v. United States.
Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-
of-time denied.
   No. 02M105. Carlayne Sims, Petitioner v. New Providence, et al.
Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-
of-time denied.
   No. 02M107. Jesse V. Myers, Petitioner v. Department of Agricul-
ture. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari
out-of-time denied.
